title: Detecting OOD Samples via Optimal Transport Scoring Function
author: Heng Gao (ISTBI Fudan University), Zhuolin He (School of Computer Science Fudan University), Jian Pu (ISTBI Fudan University), ...
relevance_why: The proposed method for out-of-distribution detection could be beneficial in audio and speech applications, especially for ensuring reliable real-world performance of models trained on audio data.
background: The task is to identify whether a test sample in deep learning comes from the in-distribution or is an unseen out-of-distribution sample during its inference phase.
contribution: This paper introduces a novel out-of-distribution detection method based on optimal transport theory to enhance performance without needing additional training data.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often rely on softmax probabilities or logits, which can be limited in capturing the underlying geometric relationships of data distributions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work employs Wasserstein distances from optimal transport theory to better characterize the discrepancies between in-distribution and out-of-distribution samples.

key_innovation: Integrates feature, logits, and softmax probability spaces to calculate out-of-distribution scores, leveraging optimal transport distances.
real_world_impact: The findings improve the reliability of machine learning models in real-world applications by enhancing their ability to detect unknown inputs, which could mitigate risks in safety-critical systems.
limitations: No specific limitations were mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.Wasserstein distance: **Wasserstein distance** is a measure of the distance between two probability distributions, often used to assess the similarity between distributions in machine learning contexts.
new_terms.optimal transport: **Optimal transport** refers to a mathematical theory for finding the most efficient way to transform one distribution into another.
